Stefen: I have seen these before but I could never reproduce them reliably.  Could you clear your log and try to provide any details on when this is happening?  For better or worse a restart will probably stop this problem from happening because it looks like the tree is hanging on to a disposed node somehow.  I need to figure out if it is something in our code or in UI/SWT.
I haven't been able to figure out how to reproduce this reliably either. After a restart the errors did not occur again.

Hit this again while disabling "Focus on workweek" mode on a filtered task list. The Eclipse instance had been idle for a while so I suspect background synchronization could have changed the task list contents.
Have you checked your elements' equals() and hashCode() methods yet?

Boris: thanks for the pointer, I didn't realize that this could be the culprit.  The identity of almost all elements in the Task List is based on String identifiers.  

All: please reopen if you ever see this stack trace in your log again.  I haven't verified that this is fixed but can't reproduce.

Rob: fyi, I checked the entire hierarchy and made the following changes, please review 3-4 below.

1) AbstractTaskContainer: the compareTo idiom was weird, not sure if it could have had side effects for some of the types.
	from: this.getHandleIdentifier().compareTo(((AbstractTask) obj).getHandleIdentifier()) == 0;
	to: this.getHandleIdentifier().equals(((AbstractTask) obj).getHandleIdentifier());
2) AbstractTaskCategory: added overrides for hashCode() and equals() because generation of hashCode() and equals() in subclasses was complaining that they needed to be there (I'm not aware of this limitation in the JLS, but fine to have).
3) ScheduledTaskDelegate: included the start/end fields
4) ScheduledTaskContainer: left as based on start/end dates
